When a woman finds out she’s pregnant, it should be the happiest day of her life. 
And it is for Ellen in Joe Ahearne ’s new BBC psychological thriller The Replacement - until Paula comes in and takes over her job as senior architect while she goes on maternity leave. 
It immediately seems Paula - played by This Is England’s Vicky McClure - is more enthusiastic than the norm to take over Ellen’s big project, even offering to come in the office and work unpaid for a day to “get to grips with everything”. 
Ellen - played by Grantchester's Morven Christie - and Paula work together for a few weeks, and during this overlap she starts to suspect there's an ulterior motive. 
Ellen finds she is cut out of meetings and finally is manoeuvred into doing something really serious that gets her into a lot of trouble - Single White Female-style. And it seems Paula is going to make Ellen’s maternity leave even worse over the course of the three episodes. 
But Vicky insisted there isn’t anything female-only about their characters’ relationship in the workplace. 
Speaking to the Radio Times, Vicky said: “Men fall out as much as women fall out. 
“Some of the dramas I hear from men... it’s the same. It doesn’t matter. 
“You have dramas within your family, with your mates, with your girlfriends. “If ever you fall out with your girlfriends, sometimes it can be quite dramatic... especially if you’re drunk, if that’s all going on. Yes, women can be bitchy, but so can men." 
Without giving too much away, Vicky went on to confess her character is “twisted”, but there’s a reason for it. 
She said: “I think a lot of characters that I’ve played, you’re sort of thrown into the deep end and you think, they’ve got a bad side, but there’s a reason for [the way Paula is]. 
“But don’t get me wrong, she’s twisted. She’s a hairy spider.”
